description: Being overweight or obese, especially after menopause, increases your risk. Regular exercise and a balanced diet are crucial for maintaining a healthy weight.
Regular exercise can lower your risk. Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise per week.
Focus on a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Limit processed foods, red meat, and sugary drinks.
Even small amounts of alcohol can increase your risk. If you drink alcohol, do so in moderation. Ideally, avoiding alcohol is the best option.
Smoking is linked to an increased risk of various cancers, including breast cancer.
If possible, breastfeeding can offer some protective benefits.
Limit the use of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) after menopause, as it can increase your risk. Discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor.

Regular mammograms and clinical breast exams can help detect breast cancer early, when it's most treatable. Talk to your doctor about the appropriate screening schedule for you based on your age and risk factors.
If you have a strong family history of breast cancer, consider genetic counseling and testing to assess your risk of inherited gene mutations (such as BRCA1 and BRCA2).
For women at high risk, medications like tamoxifen or raloxifene, or preventive surgery, may be options. Discuss these with your doctor.
Schedule regular checkups with your doctor to discuss your breast health and risk factors.
Be aware of any changes in your breasts, such as lumps, skin changes, or nipple discharge, and report them to your doctor immediately.
